Comment: There’s an elderly homeless lady in my community and as I was walking past her the other day a man who was also walking past stopped to ask her her story. She said she and her daughter lost their house back east last year. I couldn’t stick around to hear the rest but coming to California from out of state as an older homeless person certainly is not going to get you out of poverty! But the weather is livable.
Author: SAINTnumberFIVE

Comment: This is a common piece of misinformation unfortunately. The vast majority of people who are homeless in California are from California — and most are still living in the same county where they lost their housing, according to a recent large-scale survey of unhoused Californians conducted by the UCSF Benioff Homelessness and Housing Initiative. The survey found that [**90% of participants were from California**](https://homelessness.ucsf.edu/sites/default/files/2023-06/CASPEH_Report_62023.pdf) (meaning they lived in California when they became homeless) and 75% lived in the same county where they were last housed.  The sad truth is that my states social and economic climate is hostile to Californians who are struggling.
Author: Okratas

Comment: The UCSFBH study just echo's the point in time studies by Los Angeles (LASHA) and San Francisco which also reported that homeless individuals were overwhelmingly from California. The data has been very consistent over the past decade. The Los Angeles data showed that roughly 66% of those surveyed were born in California. The data has been consistent and the truth is that our economic environment and hostile cost of living, pushes people in California out of their homes and onto the streets.  > Sixty-five percent of the homeless people in Los Angeles County have **lived in L.A. County for more than 20 years**, according to LAHSA's 2018 demographic survey.   * [Your Homeless Neighbors Have Probably Lived In LA Longer Than You](https://laist.com/news/los-angeles-homeless-demographic-race-gender)
